repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Additional Financing for the Energy
            Services Delivery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Additional Financing for
            the Energy Services Delivery Project for Benin were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            despite many competing needs in the energy sector, projects
            should remain selective in their objectives and simple in
            their design. The combination of power sector reforms,
            transmission/distribution investments, and biomass energy
            activities reflected an overly ambitious and diffuse
            approach that could have benefited from further reflection
            on sector priorities and risks. Expectations for private
            sector participation need to be realistic and necessary
            preconditions should be clearly identified and achievable.
            It is important to note that the privatization of a state
            owned electricity utility, such as SBEE (Societe Beninoise
            d'Energie Electrique - Benin Distribution Power
            Utility), should therefore be based on its specific
            condition rather than on a structural liberalization or
            privatization program. Project objectives and targets should
            account for endogenous and exogenous risks potentially
            impacting outcomes and recognize inherent interdependency in
            the value chain. Institutional development is a
            transaction-intensive and time-consuming process and such
            activities should be advanced as much as possible during
            project preparation while being given sufficient priority in
            project design and implementation.

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Stepping up growth and economic diversification

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile is about stepping
            up growth and economic diversification in Benin. The global
            economic and financial crisis has contributed to a
            significant economic slowdown in Benin, and a widening of
            the fiscal and current account deficits. Despite progress in
            improving access to basic services, achieving the Millennium
            Development Goals (MDGs) remains a significant challenge.
            Benin is on track to meet the MDGs for access to potable
            water in rural areas, eradicating hunger, and reduced
            HIV/AIDS prevalence. The International Development
            Association (IDA) Country Assistance Strategies have
            supported Benin’s efforts to implement core priorities
            established in its poverty reduction strategies. In June
            2010, the IMF approved a three-year Extended Credit Facility
            (ECF) arrangement for Benin, and called for urgent action to
            reduce the fiscal deficit, restore macroeconomic stability,
            and make progress on economic reforms. Benin is one of the
            heavily indebted countries that have graduated from the
            Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative, receiving 100
            percent cancellation of eligible debt under the Multilateral
            Debt Relief Initiative. Under the ongoing Country Assistance
            Strategy (CAS), the Bank has relied on a combination of
            development policy and investment operations in order to
            encourage a coherent approach to supporting structural
            reforms. The government’s Growth Strategy for Poverty
            Reduction (2011-2015), is to make Benin an emerging economy
            by 2025.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Electricity Services Delivery
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Electricity Services Delivery Project, which aims to
            interconnect the load centers in northern Togo and northern
            Benin with the existing power grid. Negative environmental
            impacts likely to result include destruction of trees and
            vegetation during the setting out and clearing and grubbing
            operations; temporary interference with fauna during
            construction; involuntary displacement of people; loss of
            village property rights on land, caused by involuntary
            displacement and legal restrictions prohibiting farmers from
            planting trees on land needed for construction, service
            roads, and transformer stations; nuisances related to
            construction activities, such as sanitation risks, noise,
            air pollution from dust, increased risk of disease (HIV),
            Mitigation measures comprise clearing to preserve shrubbery
            along forest embankments; providing compensation at market
            value, especially to women, for loss of land and for loss of
            income-generating activities from plantations; launching an
            information campaign during project planning and
            implementation; using local labor; maintaining sanitary
            conditions; preventing the transmission of sexually
            transmitted diseases; respecting cultural sensibilities;
            preventing polluting practices; observing rites that
            preserve cultural values; establishing procedures to halt
            work when cultural artifacts are uncovered; developing
            environmental standards; and building the capacity of the
            implementing agency, CEB, the bi-national entity responsible
            for electricity generation and transmission in Benin and Togo.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Electricity Services Delivery
            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Electricity Services Delivery
            Project aims to interconnect the load centers in northern
            Togo and northern Benin with the existing power grid. The
            component giving rise to involuntary settlement is the
            establishment of a right-of-way in the corridor where a high
            voltage line is being built. People with dwellings in the
            corridor have to be displaced; villages will lose property
            rights on lands crossed by the line; crops cannot be grown
            on sites where lattice towers, substations, and
            access/service roads will be built; and people will lose
            their livelihood from trees that will have to be felled
            because of construction. The transmission line route will
            avoid villages or large concentrations of human habitations.
            As a result, existing on existing buildings are confined to
            dispersed housing clusters remote from population centers,
            and a route will be modified to avoid dislocating ten
            families. Each family displaced will be compensated
            according to the nature and surface area of their dwelling,
            and to the elements of their holdings inventoried. Each
            village having lands crossed by the corridor will be
            compensated for land loss due to an easement, for income
            loss related to trees used as an economic resource, for land
            acquired from them to build substations, and for farm income
            loss. Owners of huts or houses will be paid the replacement
            cost of another dwelling , and in some villages the
            acquisition cost of the plot itself is also included. For
            those families who had not invested in the upkeep of their
            property or who got an early start on rebuilding when
            hearing of the project and now find themselves in
            difficulties as a consequence, they are also eligible to
            receive compensation: the implementing agency (the
            bi-national electricity board, CEB) will grant a lump-sum
            compensation to be used for a community project to each
            community losing property rights on sections of their
            property; CEB will pay an indemnity equal to the cost of
            preparing the soil of replacement farmland to compensate
            farmers for land loss-farmers will be allowed to harvest
            prior to works and refrain from planting new crops within
            the project-affected area; CEB will acquire land for
            substation construction at market prices; and CEB will pay
            compensation to fruit tree  and timber stand owners and
            beneficiaries based on replacement cost or market prices.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Additional Financing for the Energy
            Services Delivery Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the
            Additional Financing for the Energy Services Delivery
            Project (ESDP) for Benin are to: (a) accelerate, in a
            commercially viable manner, the use of electricity for
            economic growth and social services and thus improve the
            quality of life in un-served and underserved areas
            (peri-urban and rural); (b) improve governance and ensure
            the financial sustainability of the sector, through the
            involvement of the private sector in partnership with the
            public sector; (c) reduce deforestation and increase access
            and diversify choice to renewable and cleaner fuels to the
            household and SME sectors; and (d) promote regional
            cooperation while protecting the environment in a
            sustainable manner. The project's implementation
            progress has been rated marginally satisfactory with the key
            investment components foreseen under the project, which
            account for 58 percent of the project's financing,
            accomplished: the northern Togo - northern Benin
            transmission line is complete and fully operational barring
            a few minor technical issues that are being addressed by the
            contractor. The rehabilitation and expansion measures, which
            were to enhance electricity supply in Cotonou and Porto
            Novo, are also complete. Under all other components,
            important milestones have also been achieved. In June 2010,
            72 percent of the financing of the ESDP was disbursed, while
            for the ESDP's additional financing 9 percent were
            disbursed. This leaves SDR 8.6million and 3.8 million to be
            disbursed over the extended period of the project.
